summary: The House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) was a committee of the United States House of Representatives established in 1976 to investigate the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King, Jr. The documents provided highlight various aspects of the HSCA's work. One document details the costs associated with the preparation of the Report of the Forensic Pathology Panel to the HSCA, indicating the committee's reliance on expert analysis. Another document summarizes an interview conducted by the HSCA regarding a Special Security Officer at Langley AFB, suggesting the committee's investigation extended to individuals with potential knowledge related to the JFK assassination. A journal entry from the Office of Legislative Counsel mentions security matters related to the HSCA, indicating the committee's interaction with other governmental bodies.
key_connections: University of New Mexico School of Medicine
significance: The HSCA played a significant role in the JFK assassination context by conducting an official investigation into the circumstances surrounding the assassination. The committee sought information from various sources, including forensic experts and individuals with potential knowledge, to determine the facts and circumstances of the assassination. The HSCA's work contributed to the historical record and continues to be a subject of interest and debate.
